questions.question: What is neuroplasticity?
options: The irreversible maturation of neural circuits
The ability of neural circuits to change in response to experience
The genetic determination of brain structure
The degeneration of synapses with age
questions.feedback: Neuroplasticity refers to the brain’s ability to change in response to experience.

questions.question: Experience modifies neural circuits primarily by changing:
questions.feedback: Experience alters the effectiveness of synaptic connections.

questions.question: Which statement best captures the interaction between genes and experience?
options: Genes and experience interact throughout life
Experience has no effect on development
questions.feedback: Genes and experience interact continuously across the lifespan.

questions.question: At birth, the human brain is:
questions.feedback: Human brain development continues well beyond birth.

questions.question: Which process refers to the generation of neurons during development?
questions.feedback: Neurogenesis is the generation of neurons.

questions.question: Which developmental process involves programmed cell death?
questions.feedback: Apoptosis eliminates excess or improperly connected cells.

questions.question: Which developmental process improves conduction speed along axons?
questions.feedback: Myelination increases conduction velocity.

questions.question: Gene specification primarily guides:
questions.feedback: Genes guide early developmental processes.

questions.question: Individual experience primarily influences:
questions.feedback: Experience guides final phases of circuit maturation.

questions.question: Synaptic plasticity refers to:
questions.feedback: Synaptic plasticity modifies communication between neurons.

questions.question: Functional synaptic plasticity involves:
options: Changes in efficacy of existing synapses
questions.feedback: Functional plasticity changes synaptic strength.

questions.question: Structural synaptic plasticity includes:
options: Changes in ion channel kinetics only
Formation or elimination of synaptic contacts
questions.feedback: Structural plasticity modifies synaptic architecture.

questions.question: Adult neurogenesis occurs primarily in:
questions.feedback: Adult neurogenesis is restricted mainly to the hippocampus.

questions.question: Hebb’s principle states that synapses strengthen when:
questions.feedback: Correlated activity strengthens synaptic connections.

questions.question: The phrase “neurons that fire together, wire together” summarizes:
questions.feedback: This is the core idea of Hebbian plasticity.

questions.question: Which receptor acts as a coincidence detector?
questions.feedback: NMDA receptors require presynaptic and postsynaptic activity.

questions.question: Why is the NMDA receptor blocked at resting potential?
questions.feedback: Magnesium blocks the NMDA channel at rest.

questions.question: NMDA receptor activation allows entry of:
questions.feedback: Calcium influx triggers plasticity mechanisms.

questions.question: Long-term potentiation (LTP) is defined as:
questions.feedback: LTP produces long-lasting synaptic strengthening.

questions.question: One immediate effect of LTP is:
questions.feedback: LTP increases AMPA receptor insertion.

questions.question: Morphological changes in LTP typically occur:
questions.feedback: Structural plasticity stabilizes long-term changes.

questions.question: Long-term depression (LTD) involves:
questions.feedback: LTD weakens synaptic transmission.

questions.question: Functional LTD typically involves:
questions.feedback: AMPA receptor removal reduces synaptic strength.

questions.question: LTP and LTD together allow circuits to:
options: Strengthen relevant and weaken irrelevant connections
questions.feedback: Plasticity is about balance, not just strengthening.

questions.question: Why is Hebbian plasticity alone unstable?
options: It leads to runaway excitation or silence
questions.feedback: Unregulated Hebbian plasticity destabilizes networks.

questions.question: Homeostatic plasticity primarily functions to:
questions.feedback: Homeostatic mechanisms keep activity within functional ranges.

questions.question: When neural activity is chronically high, homeostatic plasticity:
questions.feedback: Global downscaling prevents runaway excitation.

questions.question: Homeostatic plasticity preserves:
questions.feedback: Relative synaptic weights are maintained.

questions.question: Who demonstrated adult neurogenesis in birds?
questions.feedback: Nottebohm overturned the dogma of no adult neurogenesis.

questions.question: In adult mammals, neurogenesis occurs mainly in:
questions.feedback: Adult neurogenesis is restricted to the dentate gyrus.

questions.question: Approximately how many new hippocampal neurons are generated per day in humans?
questions.feedback: About 700 new neurons are generated daily.

questions.question: Pattern separation refers to:
options: Separating similar experiences into distinct representations
questions.feedback: Pattern separation reduces interference.

questions.question: The dentate gyrus is thought to support:
questions.feedback: Dentate gyrus helps separate similar contexts.

questions.question: Systems consolidation involves:
options: Transfer of memories from hippocampus to cortex
questions.feedback: Memories gradually become cortex-dependent.

questions.question: Increasing adult neurogenesis tends to:
questions.feedback: More neurogenesis accelerates consolidation.

questions.question: Environmental enrichment tends to:
questions.feedback: Enrichment enhances plasticity.

questions.question: Physical exercise in humans is associated with:
questions.feedback: Exercise enhances hippocampal function.
